'''''Hygrocybe miniata''''', commonly known as the '''vermilion waxcap''', is a small, bright red or red-orange [[mushroom]] of the waxcap genus ''[[Hygrocybe]]''. It is a [[cosmopolitan distribution|cosmopolitan]] species, that is found worldwide. In Europe, it is found in fields, on sandy heaths, or grassy commons in the autumn (fall).<ref name=Phillips06>{{cite book | author = Phillips, Roger | year = 2006  | title = Mushrooms | publisher = Pan MacMillan | isbn = 978-0-330-44237-4|page= 74}}</ref> It is found in rainforest and [[eucalypt]] forest as well as heathland in Australia.

==Taxonomy==
''Hygrocybe miniata'' was first described by Swedish mycologist [[Elias Magnus Fries]] as ''Agaricus miniatus'' in 1821, before being renamed by the same author in 1838 as ''Hygrophorus miniatus''. German mycologist [[Paul Kummer]] then assigned it to the genus ''[[Hygrocybe]]'' in 1871. The [[specific name (botany)|specific epithet]] ''miniata'' comes from ‘miniat’, which means "painted with red lead".<ref name=Arora2nd>{{cite book |author=David Arora |year=1986 |title=Mushrooms Demystified |publisher=Ten Speed Press |isbn=978-0-89815-169-5 |url-access=registration |url=https://archive.org/details/mushroomsdemysti00aror_0 }}</ref>

==Description==
The [[Pileus (mycology)|cap]] is convex initially, but later flattens and becomes depressed with a wavy edges. The centre of mature fruiting bodies is noticeably scurfy, or scaly. This is a feature that is best seen on dry specimens, that have not been rained on. The cap colour is scarlet-orange with a yellow striate margin, and is 0.5–3.5 cm in diameter. The bare [[Stipe (mycology)|stem]] is often long, (up to 3 times the cap diameter) and tapering towards the base, with a tendency to flatten. It is the same colour as the cap, or slightly paler, with a white base.<ref name=Phillips06/> The [[Lamella (mycology)|gills]] are orange, adnate (with a broad attachment to the stem) or slightly decurrent; widely spaced, and somewhat notched. The [[trama (mycology)|flesh]] is orange, and is devoid of any odour. The [[spore print]] is white, and the [[wikt:ellipsoid|ellipsoid]] [[basidiospore|spores]] measure 7–9 x 4–5 [[micrometre|μm]].<ref name=Phillips06/><ref name=C&D1995>{{cite book | author = Regis Courtecuisse and Bernard Duhem  | year = (British version) 1995 | title = Mushrooms and Toadstools of Britain and Europe | publisher = Harper Collins | isbn = 978-0-00-220025-7}}</ref>

A very similar species (only recently described) ''[[Hygrocybe helobi|H. helobi]]'' (Arnolds) Bon; appears earlier in the season, prefers less acidic soils, and smells of garlic.<ref name=T.Laessoe>{{cite book | author = Thomas Laessoe | year = 1998 | title = Mushrooms (flexi bound) | publisher = Dorling Kindersley | isbn = 978-0-7513-1070-2}}</ref>

==Distribution and habitat==
''Hygrocybe miniata'' is a [[cosmopolitan distribution|cosmopolitan]] species, having been recorded in most of the [[temperate]] zones. It has been collected from Britain, Europe, America,<ref name=Arora2nd/> and the equivalent zones in the Southern Hemisphere such as eastern and southern Australia, where it has been recorded from [[Queensland]], [[New South Wales]], [[Victoria (Australia)|Victoria]] and [[Tasmania]].<ref name=Young05>{{cite book | author= Young, A.M. | year =2005 | title = Fungi of Australia: Hygrophoraceae | publisher = (Australian Biological Resources Study) CSIRO, Canberra, ACT | isbn = 978-0-643-09195-5|page = 120}}</ref>

In Britain it appears in autumn (fall), particularly in frost free periods, and prefers sandy heaths, grassy clearings, or unimproved fields.<ref name=Phillips06/> It is often seen in the company of [[mouse-ear hawkweed]] (''Hieracium pilosella'').<ref name=T.Laessoe/>

In Australia, it can be found in temperate to [[subtropical]] rainforest and [[eucalypt]] forest as well as heathland. Fruiting bodies may appear in groups among the leaf litter from January to June.<ref name=Young05/>

==Edibility==
Edible, but of no consequence.
